headline.main: Study Shows Health Benefit for Immigrants

docs.abstract: Report, synthesis of several national studies by David and Lucile Packard Foundation, reveals that immigrant and foreign-born children living in US are healthier than those of same age who were born here; is issued by National Institutes of Health; suggests that English-language barrier helps protect them from risks of obesity, asthma and other health conditions that affect many American children (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: More than half the children under 7 in New York City are growing up in immigrant families, and in many of them no one over 13 speaks English well. But a new report released yesterday suggests that this linguistic isolation helps protect them from the higher rates of obesity, asthma, and adolescent risk-taking that afflict native-born and Americanized children. Though the report also cautions that the language barriers make it harder for children to get the health insurance and education they need, it finds that foreign-born children are healthier when they arrive in the United States than those of the same age who were born here.
docs.snippet: A new report suggests that immigrant children are better protected from higher rates of obesity, asthma, and adolescent risk-taking than native-born and Americanized children.

headline.main: With Fruits and Vegetables, More Can Be Less

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses benefits of eating more fruits and vegetables as part of weight-loss plan; Dr Barbara J Rolls, Penn State University behavioral health professor and author of The Volumetrics Weight-Control Plan: Feel Full on Fewer Calories, describes concept of energy density and how it effects caloric intake; importance of water in diet discussed; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: What determines how much we eat and how much we weigh? Is it the amount of fat in foods, the presence of carbohydrates, the size of our portions, what we drink with our meals, that elusive trait called willpower? Conflicting popular advice can prompt would-be dieters to give up before they even start. The good news based on solid research is that you can eat more -- probably more food than you're now eating -- and weigh less, if you choose more of the right kinds of foods.
docs.snippet: You can eat more  probably more food than you're now eating  and weigh less, if you choose more of the right kinds of foods.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Car Bombs Kill 41, Most of Them Children A pair of car bombs tore through a street celebration marking the opening of a new sewer plant, killing 41 Iraqis, at least 34 of them children, and wounding and maiming 139 more, in one of the most horrific attacks in Baghdad since the fall of Saddam Hussein. A1 American and Iraqi soldiers launched a military assault on Samarra, in what appeared to be the first major operation to retake areas from rebels before elections. A6 The Bush administration is pressing wealthy countries to come up with money to help fill the gap created by its recent decision to divert funds in Iraq from reconstruction into security and job creation. A6 Eroding Kurdish Gains in Turkey Kurds have begun to achieve a modicum of economic progress and cultural freedom, but at the same time, Kurdish militants have taken up arms in southeastern Turkey. A8 31 Killed in Israeli Offensive At least 28 Palestinians and three Israelis were killed as Israeli troops pushed into a refugee camp in the Gaza Strip and battled militants. The fighting, combined with warnings from Israeli officials, pointed to the possibility of a large-scale military offensive in Gaza directed at the Palestinian factions responsible for almost daily attacks. A3 Russian Global Warming Treaty Russia's cabinet endorsed the long-delayed Kyoto Protocol on global warming treaty and sent it to parliament. A1 Secretary General Front-runner Thailand's foreign minister, Surakiart Sathirathai, has emerged as an early favorite to succeed Kofi Annan as United Nations secretary general when his term ends in 2006. A6 NATIONAL A12-24 Bush and Kerry Clash Over Iraq in Debate Senator John Kerry, in his first face-to-face encounter with President Bush, argued last night that Mr. Bush had made a ''colossal error of judgment'' in invading Iraq, while Mr. Bush belittled Mr. Kerry as a weak leader whose shifting opinions would embolden America's foes. A1 Panel Critical of DeLay The House ethics committee determined that the majority leader, Tom DeLay, should be admonished for improperly trying to win the vote of a Michigan lawmaker during a floor fight over a health bill. A1 Airport Security Increased Officials began photographing and electronically fingerprinting travelers from 27 industrialized nations, including England and France. A13 Drug Bills Vetoed in California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger vetoed several bills that would have made the state the middleman in large-scale purchases of prescription drugs from Canada. A12 Cuban Scholars Denied Visas The Bush administration has denied entry to all 61 Cuban scholars scheduled to participate in an international congress in Las Vegas. A15 Ban on Gay Unions Blocked A proposed constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage failed in the House of Representatives, a defeat the measure's Republican backers promptly vowed to wield against Democrats in the November election. A14 Deportation Delayed for Hamdi The administration postponed deporting Yaser E. Hamdi, the Saudi-American captured in Afghanistan in 2001, because of Saudi government objections to requirements that it monitor him for five years. A13 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Mayor Demands Inquiry Into Ex-Senator's Release Mayor Bloomberg said he asked the New York City Department of Investigation to examine how a city commission run by mayoral appointees granted former State Senator Guy J. Velella an early release from jail. B1 Law Firms Must Defend Fees A New York State judge told law firms that they must justify the contingency fees they charged to represent families before the federal September 11th Victim Compensation Fund. She left open the possibility that she might reduce them. B3 Woman, 76, Fatally Stabbed A 76-year-old Brooklyn woman fought back against a robber who stabbed her half a dozen times, but died after staggering two blocks into a police station and collapsing on the floor, the authorities said. B1 FASHION B9 WEEKEND E1-26;E27-36 ESCAPES F1-14 SPORTSFRIDAY D1-6 OBITUARIES A25 SCIENCE/HEALTH Obesity Deemed Societal Ill A report on the causes and solutions for childhood obesity in the United States calls for a societal strategy, including healthier meals in schools and restaurants. A24 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 Arthritis Drug Withdrawn Merck said it would stop selling its arthritis and pain medication Vioxx because a new study found that it doubled patients' risk of heart attack and strokes. A1 U.S. Willing to Forgive Debt The United States and is nearing an agreement with international financial institutions to forgive all the government debts of many of the world's poorest countries. C1 Trade Dispute Unresolved Top trade officials for the United States and the European Union failed to resolve their dispute over government subsidies to aircraft manufacturers, inching closer to a clash. C5 Fannie Mae Investigation The Justice Department started an investigation of Fannie Mae in response to a report accusing executives of sloppy accounting practices, a government official said. C3 Business Digest C1 World Business W1 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: The first debate; ending the cycle of debt; demise of a blockbuster drug; not in America. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Crossword E26 TV Listings E25 Public Lives B4 Weather D7

headline.main: New Strategy On Obesity In Children Is Urged

docs.abstract: Comprehensive report on causes and solutions for childhood obesity in United States takes new approach, calling for broad societal strategy rather than focusing on personal responsibility; proposals, by National Academies' Institute of Medicine, include healthier meals in schools and restaurants, more opportunities for physical education at schools and in communities, restrictions in television advertising to children, and education of health professionals and children to make better choices; report is presented to Congress; it was requested by Sen Tom Harkin (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A comprehensive report on the causes and solutions for childhood obesity in the United States has taken a new approach to the epidemic. The report, which was released on Thursday by a panel of top researchers, calls for a broad societal strategy rather than focusing on personal responsibility. The proposals, by the National Academies' Institute of Medicine, include healthier meals in schools and restaurants; more opportunities for physical education at schools and in communities; restrictions in television advertising to children; and education of health professionals and children to make better choices.
docs.snippet: A report on the causes and solutions for childhood obesity in the United States calls for a broad societal strategy, including healthier meals in schools and restaurants.
